description: Dive into "Discover Nara's Hidden Free Gems" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Discover Nara's Hidden Free Gems

places.generalDescription: Naramachi Koshi-no-Ie, also known as Lattice House, is a replica of a traditional merchant townhouse with a charming wooden lattice exterior. This well-kept facility offers visitors a glimpse into the lifestyle of merchants in the area, showcasing high-ceilinged kitchen areas and unique features like the hako kaidan staircase that doubled as a chest of drawers.

sources.shortName: Nara on a Budget! Free Attractions and Tasty Local Dishes

places.name: Naramachi Koshi-no-Ie (Lattice House)

reviews.text: Worth the visit for sure! It is free and the staff is very nice and kind. Inside of the old traditional house with little courtyard! At the end she offerred us an origami for gift. I will remember this place and the kind lady for life!
Location is along a small lane amongst residential and shops. Entry is free. Very quiet and leisurely place. Require to remove shoes

Great typical house of Edo period. You can enter for free until 17.00h. You also have to take out your shoes. House is well conservated and everything is explained inside. It is possible to take incredible photos of how an old Naramachi house looked like!!

places.generalDescription: Mount Wakakusa is a 1,122-foot tall hill in Nara, Japan. It hosts the annual festival called Yamayaki, during which dead grass is burned. The hill offers stunning views and is a popular attraction among visitors to Nara Park. The area is also known for its wild deer population, with two types of deer residing in the region: "park deer" and "Mount Wakakusa deer." Both types primarily feed on various grasses found in the area.

sources.snippet: Although it only reaches a height of around 350 meters, Mount Wakakusa boasts one of the best views of Nara. The grass-covered mount lies just behind Nara Park, with some lovely cherry blossom trees dotted here and there. The hike to the top should take just under an hour, although most people stop off at a plateau which lies halfway up, as the view from there is just as stunning.
sources.shortName: Best Things to do in Nara, Japan (+Map)

sources.snippet: Mount Wakakusa, also known as Wakakusayama, offers a gentle hike with panoramic views of Nara City and the surrounding countryside. The hike is free and particularly popular during the cherry blossom season when the slopes are dotted with pink blossoms. The grassy hillside is also the site of the annual Wakakusa Yamayaki, a grass-burning festival held in January.
sources.shortName: 7 Free Things to Do in Nara

sources.snippet: awu45If the deer in Nara are a must-see feature of a trip to Kansai, Japan, then watching the sunset with the deer on Mount Wakakusa is definitely the most romantic place in Kansai!. üìùCheck-in guide: From Nara Park ‚û°Ô∏èKasuga Taisha ‚û°Ô∏èTodaiji Temple ‚û°Ô∏èMount Wakakusa, there are deer everywhere. You can buy some deer biscuits and take photos with them.

Nara Park is a massive park at the foot of Mt. Wakakusa full of very playful and friendly deer. The natural setting includes temples set in unspoiled woods and a lake full of turtles and carp. The temples and shrines of Nara are much older than the oft-rebuilt buildings in Kyoto, and much more unique.
sources.shortName: Nara Park | Nara | Kansai | Destinations | Travel Japan

sources.snippet: If you visit Nara in January, you can see an interesting event. On the fourth Saturday of each January, there is an event of burning grass on 342 m high Mt. Wakakusa-yama. It is a traditional event that takes place throughout history, continued since the mid-18th century.
sources.shortName: Top Attractions in Japan‚Äôs Ancient Capital of Nara
22 Unforgettable Things to Do in Nara

places.name: Mount Wakakusa

reviews.text:
A lovely hike for those wanting to escape the crowds in the park below. Don't miss out on doing the full loop, as there is a very peaceful forested section on the way back down.

Took us about 1.5 hr roundtrip but we took a nice break at the top to enjoy the beautiful views.
Beautiful view and a peaceful hike! The scenery from the top was stunning, especially overlooking Nara. A lovely place to enjoy nature and spot some deer along the way.

The deer is very cute and not afraid of people. The entrance ticket to the mountain is very cheap, only 150 yen. The scenery at the top of the mountain is very beautiful, making it an excellent place to overlook Nara.

places.generalDescription: Kakinohasushi Hompo Tanaka is a traditional restaurant in Nara that serves sushi wrapped in kaki (persimmon) leaves. This unique presentation harks back to the olden days when sushi had to be transported overland to Nara, far from the coast. The persimmon leaves not only have antibacterial properties that kept the fish fresh but also imparted a delicate fragrance, enhancing the flavor of the fish.

sources.snippet: Kakinoha Sushi Tanaka is one of many specialty stores that specialise in this particular dish. The location we visited was near the entrance of the Higashimuki Shopping Street (Êù±ÂêëÂïÜÂ∫óË°ó) near the Kintetsu Nara Train Station (ËøëÈâÑÂ•àËâØÈßÖ) and just a couple of minutes‚Äô walk from the Nara Prefectural Building. We opted for the 7-piece lunchbox, which comes with two pieces of tai sea bream (ÈØõ), two pieces of sake salmon („Åï„Åë), and three pieces of saba mackerel for ¬•1,177 after tax (US$10.60).
sources.shortName: Nara on a Budget! Free Attractions and Tasty Local Dishes

places.name: Kakinoha Sushi Honpo Tanaka Nara Honten

reviews.text:
Think not many foreigners realise they have a small dine-in place ( "Kakinoha Chaya" Êüø„ÅÆËëâËå∂Â±ã) at this main shop. Walk in and let the shop attendants know you will like to have the Kakinohasushi in-house and they will usher u to a queue where one puts in your name and wait to be seated

No need to search high and low for a dustbin which is a rarity in Japan ahaha

Lovely little quiet space to enjoy their sushi. The set comes with a most refined dash soup and a cup of tea. And they will provide diners with carriers to takeout any sushi they cannot finish

A most pleasant dining experience here as their staff were all very affable and professional even though we are not conversant in Japanese

This place is renowned for its traditional pressed sushi, wrapped in persimmon leaves. The taste is quite unique and interesting, though it may not appeal to everyone. Personally, I found it a bit underwhelming-perhaps because my expectations were high.

For takeaway, it's important to consume the sushi as soon as possible and keep it at the recommended temperature, as the flavor changes noticeably if not stored properly. I'd recommend grilling or heating it up, following the instructions provided in the packaging.

The price is slightly higher than other similar stores, likely due to the detailed and thoughtful packaging. However, it's worth trying if you're nearby and curious about this traditional delicacy. There's also a eat-in area within the store.

This place serves their famous sushi wrapped in leaves, all freshly made and plenty of different variations to choose from.

We ordered the prawn and salmon variations and it was pretty good. The rice was made very well and was nice to eat.

I do think it was a bit overhyped, so perhaps my expectations were too high. Worth a visit anyway if you're in Nara!

places.generalDescription: Tsukigase Plum Grove, located along the Nabari River in Nara Prefecture, Japan, is a popular spot to witness the stunning blossoming of Japanese apricot trees. The grove offers a picturesque setting with white and pink plum trees lining a steep path along the mountainside. While similar to sakura blossoms, these plums have their own unique charm and emit a sweet fragrance that fills the air during their short-lived bloom in March.

sources.snippet: Spring in Japan is known for its beautiful blossoming flowers like sakura and plum. In Tsukigase Plum Valley you can enjoy the sweet fragrance of the beautiful plum trees in full blossom. They look quite similar to sakura and also last for a short period of time.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things To Do in Nara

places.name: Tsukigase Plum Grove

reviews.text:
A few days ago, on a fine spring day, I went to the Tsukigase plum grove (Êúà„É∂ÁÄ¨Ê¢ÖÊûó) along the Nabari River in Nara Prefecture.  A steep path leads along the mountain facing the Nabari River. The trail lined with white and pink plum trees is a lovely sight.
The Tsukigase plum grove is famous here in Japan and frequently mentioned on TV during the plum blossoms season.
"The Cherry may be the prettier of the two; but when once you have seen the red Plum-blossom in the snow at the dawn of a spring morning, you will no longer forget its beauty." -Fujiwara no Kint≈ç (Ëó§Âéü ÂÖ¨‰ªª).
The fragrance of plum blossoms "comes from the bitterness and coldness," as the Japanese saying goes. Souls are tempered in the depth of experience, growing in inner strength and unyielding courage.

Great park for plum blossoms in the Spring. Lots of food and treats along the way. Beautiful views of the valley below. Best to drive but possible to use public transport from Osaka in about two hours. Parking fills up early but spaces available if you drive though the village area.

I go to see Japanese apricot blossoms here almost every year.
You can enjoy seeing massive blossoms in March, but the full blooming days are different year by year.
There are some parking place and almost all of them are for free (I guess it's so hard to get there without car).
There are also some shops sale food and drink, and so are restaurants, but I strongly recommend bringing boxed lunch because if you have that you can enjoy your meal under the blossoms! (On top of that, both shops and restaurants are expensive!)
You can walk dogs around here.
